prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: The Panel Rules require that a brief or memorandum be filed in support of every motion before the Panel.[1] Rather than a mere fulfillment of a formal requirement, however, the brief should be viewed as an opportunity for persuasion. Many briefs filed with the Panel advance solely parochial viewpoints of individual litigants or attempt to rely on Panel decisions in different litigation as binding authority. It is most important that the brief address the fundamental issue to be decided: how can the Panel best act to advance the interests of justice and efficient and fair management of the litigation?

A memorandum filed with the Panel should address the case-management matters properly before the Panel, not the merits of the actions involved or other matters properly before either the transferee court or transferor court. An oblique criticism of counsel in one Panel decision for filing briefs directed to an unrelated issue is instructive:

The repetitive papers filed with the Panel have been of little help in identifying these common fact questions. The Panel's concern is not with the merits of the title [to a patent] issue but with the question of whether this common legal issue involves common fact questions sufficiently complex to require the use of 28 U.S.C. Section 1407.[2]

The form of briefs filed with the Panel is not significantly different from that used in any federal court. The rule requires a “concise” statement of the background of the litigation and the factual and legal contentions of the party.[3] The rule impliedly favors that these be in separate sections of the brief. To be most readable, the brief should set forth the individual arguments in separately numbered and headed paragraphs.

The Panel most frequently considers precedent in the form of its own decisions. Opinions of other courts may be considered, but are rarely germane to the issues before the Panel. The one glaring exception to this is that on questions of possible remand, the Panel is very interested in the views and actions of the transferee judge. The Panel does not have any rules relating to its own unpublished opinions, and these decisions are suitable for citation to the Panel. The Panel has cited its own unpublished decisions.[4] The Panel presumably feels that opinions it does not submit for publication are unlikely to be of significant value in the future, however, so unpublished opinions are unlikely to be of great value.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
J.P.M.L. R. 3.1(b). The Panel rules are reproduced in § 4:34.

See In re Willingham Patent, 322 F. Supp. 1019, 1020 n.1 (J.P.M.L. 1971). In more than one case, the submissions of the parties are plainly limited to the self-interest of an individual party, and therefore neither helpful to the Panel nor persuasive. See, e.g., In re Diet Drugs (Phentermine, Fenfluramine, Dexfenfluramine) Products Liability Litigation, 990 F. Supp. 834 (J.P.M.L. 1998) (referring to submissions as “in many instances motivated by transparently parochial concerns”).
See J.P.M.L. R. 6.2(b)(i). The Panel rules are reproduced in § 4:34.
See, e.g., In re Asbestos School Products Liability Litigation, 606 F. Supp. 713, 714 (J.P.M.L. 1985).
